title: Gammas â€“ A Useful AI-supported Slides Generator
text:
Smart Design Without Extra Prompting
When I first experimented with Gammas, I wasnâ€™t sure what to expect. Instead of feeding it a detailed creative brief or stylistic preferences, I simply pasted the introduction and methodology sections of one of my research papers. That was itâ€”no formatting instructions, no design hints, no color palette guidance. To my surprise, Gammas immediately produced a set of clean, well-structured slides.



What made it interesting was how different they looked from a traditional PowerPoint or Google Slides deck. Each slideâ€”or rather, each cardâ€”was dynamically sized according to the amount of content it held. If a page contained more text, charts, or visuals, it expanded to fit; if it only had a short title and a single image, it became compact. This layout approach felt more like a fluid deck of cards than a static series of slides.
Each card isnâ€™t just adaptiveâ€”itâ€™s also customizable and flexible in size. When I add new layouts such as columns, boxes, or diagrams, the elements never overlap or break the structure. The entire card automatically expands and reflows to accommodate the new content, as if Gammas had already anticipated the design logic for me. It arranges the structure while still allowing room for manual adjustments. Whatâ€™s fascinating is that all this happens without any prompting. Gammas seems to understand how to balance information, white space, and visual rhythm. The initial output already looked complete enough to present, even though I hadnâ€™t given any design instructions.






Image Generation and Visual Customization
Another notable feature of Gammas is its built-in AI image generation system. By default, every image it produces is generated by AI, yet each one is editable. I can adjust the text prompt that was used to create the imageâ€”tweaking details or toneâ€”and Gammas regenerates the visual instantly. The platform also allows selection of art styles that align with the overall mood of the slidesâ€”whether minimalist, illustrative, or photorealistic. There are advanced customization options such as aspect ratio, image count, and model choice, offering a good degree of creative control within one interface.

 

Beyond AI-generated visuals, Gammas integrates web image search directly into the editor. This makes it easy to look for reference images or stock photos without leaving the workspace. It eliminates the constant tab-switching typical in PowerPoint or Google Slides. Lastly, Gammas offers accent images that automatically match the theme or palette of the presentation, adding a touch of visual coherenceâ€”even when most of the design is automated.



AI-Assisted Text Editing and Visualization
Gammasâ€™s text editing experience follows the same design logic as its layout system. It allows in-place AI editing: highlight a segment of text, then ask the AI to polish, expand, or brainstormâ€”no need to leave the editor. This built-in workflow makes it efficient to refine ideas while constructing slides.
I also appreciate the flexible styling. Any text block can be quickly transformed into formats such as â€œcode style,â€ â€œblog quote,â€ or â€œinfo box,â€ helping emphasize key points and structure information more clearly. Even more interestingly, Gammas can visualize highlighted text automatically. It interprets meaning and creates a corresponding diagram on the slide, which can switch between formats like puzzle, arrow bars, or chain. Itâ€™s a subtle but useful way to turn written content into visual logic.






Smart Diagrams and Guided Inspiration
Gammasâ€™s Smart Diagram tool includes a variety of diagram types and decorative layoutsâ€”from flowcharts to comparison grids. When inserted, each text box is automatically filled with sample content that loosely relates to the presentation topic. These placeholders are not perfect but provide a helpful starting pointâ€”a prompt for how ideas might be structured visually.
The diagrams are customizable through a monochrome palette system that keeps them visually consistent with the theme. The result is a layout that looks coherent while leaving room for personal adjustment.

 




Interactive Links and Embedded Content
Gammas redefines how links appear in slides. In most tools, a hyperlink is just underlined text. In Gammas, it can be a text link, a button, or a preview card showing a snippet of the linked page. Even more interesting, the entire website can be embedded directly into the slide, letting viewers interact with live web content without leaving the presentation. Compared with PowerPoint or Google Slides, Gammas feels more like an interactive storytelling medium than a static deck builder.






Comprehending and Structuring the Logic Behind Text
Gammas performs well in understanding and structuring the logic of my writing. Instead of just summarizing or decorating content, it interprets and reorganizes it to make the reasoning clearer.
For example, when I uploaded a section on Woodâ€™s Scaffolding Framework, Gammas recognized the hierarchical logic in my writing. It used the main concept as the slide title and listed the five scaffolding functions vertically, presenting them as parallel rather than sequential. In other words, Gammas can differentiate between parallel, nested, and sequential structures when visualizing ideas. This gives the slides a sense of internal coherence instead of mechanical assembly.



That said, its comprehension has limits. For conceptually complex relationsâ€”such as derivative frameworks or theoretical originsâ€”it sometimes misses the connection. When I discussed how Vygotskyâ€™s Zone of Proximal Development underlies Woodâ€™s Scaffolding Framework, Gammas failed to capture that evolutionary link. Still, its performance is adequate, leaving meaningful room for human reasoning and refinement.



Reflection
Overall, Gammas functions as an efficient AI-supported presentation generator. Even the initial draft it produced was coherent and visually balanced. If oneâ€™s standards arenâ€™t overly strict, the first version could already be used with only minor edits. Its integrated workflowâ€”covering image search, text refinement, and layout controlâ€”keeps everything in one place, minimizing external switching.
That said, the main limitation lies in element flexibility. You canâ€™t freely drag and position text or images as in PowerPoint; you operate within a predefined framework. Within that, you can switch styles or replace diagrams, but canâ€™t fully break the structure. To me, this design choice makes Gammas feel more like a controlled, design-consistent environment rather than a freeform canvas. For users seeking speed and structural clarity, thatâ€™s an acceptable trade-off.

title: Two Days, One Extension: How I Build My First Extension With Cline (Part 2)
text:
Takeaways
First, collaborating with AI to develop an extension or software is ideal for multitasking. Since AI needs time to process requirements, analyze the code, and propose the best strategy, I can use that waiting period to focus on other tasks. For example, while developing this extension, I also worked on writing a blog about the process. This not only saved time but also helped me keep a fresh memory of the entire workflow.
Second, itâ€™s important to remember to push the code once it reaches a satisfactory state. If you move on to the next iteration and AI introduces major changes that worsen the outcome, youâ€™ll want to revert to the earlier version â€” which is only possible if youâ€™ve pushed it beforehand. As a bonus tip, if youâ€™re unhappy with the current version, you can use git stash to temporarily save it in a separate place. That way, you can easily return to the most recent pushed version whenever needed.
Third, even though AI is capable of debugging, we still need to remain flexible and adapt to the current status of the code. Sometimes, when AI fails to achieve a goal after several attempts, it becomes necessary to explore alternative solutions. For instance, I found it useful to ask AI to generate logs and then feed those logs back into the system. This gave AI a clearer understanding of what had been accomplished and what went wrong. In other words, we cannot simply expect AI to finish the task on its own â€” we have to think critically and provide multiple options or strategies to guide it.
Finally, although describing bugs and formulating a well-structured request for ChatGPT can make inputs more organized, I noticed that sometimes a plain and simple description written directly by me led to more effective debugging. I suspect this is because ChatGPTâ€™s reorganized versions can be overly long or mundane, adding unnecessary noise for both the model and the client to process. In these cases, relying on my own straightforward explanation worked better than depending on ChatGPTâ€™s reformulations.
Throughout the creation, I found that whether it was drafting the design document or writing the code, I found that the AI considered all the essential aspects of building an extension. It even anticipated how users would navigate the extension and added many features and options beyond my original requirements, which I found quite amazing. For example, I never gave any instructions on the visual design, but GPT-5 automatically chose a sleek purple theme with gradient effects and designed the button styles and the settings page layout. I hardly made any changes to this style because it was already more than satisfactory. Later, when I asked GPT-5 to refine the design by removing the button border, it provided a detailed color specification covering three states: unselected, hover, and selected. This level of comprehensiveness went far beyond my expectations, since I wouldnâ€™t have thought to account for all those conditions. In terms of functionality, the AI also created features I hadnâ€™t considered, such as an API input bar and an option allowing users to preview the modified prompt before sending it. What impressed me most was that I didnâ€™t need to specify every detail â€” with only simple descriptions from me, the AI was able to design thoughtful features and interfaces on its own.

text:
In Chapter 3 (pages 46â€“62), Ethan lays out four rules for co-intelligenceâ€”ground rules designed to capture what is inherent and enduring across all current generative AI systems built on large language models.

Principle 3: Treat AI like a person (But tell it what kind of person it is)
Principle 4: Assume this is the worst AI you will ever use

Through everyday interactions with AI, we might stumble upon surprising, creative, and unexpected outcomes.

As a learner myself, I often remain cautious about the misuse, overuse, and potential over-reliance on AI. I worry that if I â€œalwaysâ€ turn to AI, I might lose my own agency and abilities, eventually leading to a kind of regression. Yet itâ€™s interesting to notice how Ethan approaches AI not from the standpoint of a student, but from that of a professional seeking efficiency and creativity. (After all, we canâ€™t deny that in many work contexts, AI truly does enhance speed, productivity, and creative possibility.)
For Ethan, the question is not â€œWill this weaken my ability?â€ but â€œHow can I use this to push my work further?â€
Then I realized that these standpoints are not fixed. A single person can shift between themâ€”sometimes Iâ€™m the learner worried about agency, and other times I see myself as a researcher or creator to explore what AI can make possible. ğŸ”¹ Principle 3: Treat AI like a person (But tell it what kind of person it is)

ğŸ”¹ Principle 4: Assume this is the worst AI you will ever use

â€œWhen students engage with study mode, theyâ€™re met with guiding questions that calibrate responses to their objective and skill level to help them build deeper understanding. Study mode is designed to be engaging and interactive, and to help students learn somethingâ€”not just finish something.â€ â€” OpenAI, ChatGPT Study Mode





This experiment grew out of one of my research projects on how students use ChatGPT in writing. For the study, I selected 21 prompts from the RECIPE4U dataset â€” a publicly available collection of interaction histories between 212 college students and ChatGPT in an English writing course (Sawalha et al., 2024a).
In that course, students used ChatGPT to help revise their essays, and the dataset records their entire conversations, including the original prompts, dialogue exchanges, annotated writing intentions, and final revised essays. Using a subset of these authentic prompts, I tested ChatGPTâ€™s Study Mode to see how well it supports learning-oriented writing guidance compared with ordinary prompts.




The 21 prompts we selected were all labeled â€œContent Generation.â€ Based on both my classroom observations and prior research, many college students tend to use ChatGPT primarily to generate essays directly rather than to learn or revise through it.
I wanted to test whether ChatGPTâ€™s Study Mode could truly support learning and knowledge transformationâ€”as it claims toâ€”rather than simply producing finished text. To do this, I took those prompts that originally requested direct generation and ran them in ChatGPTâ€™s Study Mode.




However, to my disappointment, 14 out of 21 responses directly produced ready-made text, just as the users originally requested. Here are some examples.



Prompt from the dataset:

Can you rewrite the body paragraph by breaking up the body paragraphs into subheadings. {the studentâ€™s essay}.

ChatGPT said:

Good â€” before I rewrite anything, letâ€™s make sure you understand why and how subheadings help.
Subheadings give readers â€œsignpostsâ€ so they can easily follow the structure of your essay. Each main idea (like Convenience, Affordability, Health Problems, etc.) becomes its own section.
Letâ€™s try this step-by-step. Your essayâ€™s body paragraphs seem to focus on three big ideas:

Convenience of Fast Food
Affordability and Accessibility
Negative Health and Social Effects


Hereâ€™s a sample outline of how those subheadings could look â€” not rewritten yet, just organized:




Explain how location, opening hours, and speed make fast food easy to access.



Describe why fast food is cheap â€” simple menus, pre-packaged ingredients, low overhead â€” and how it helps people on tight budgets.



Discuss obesity, diabetes, heart disease, and mental health issues, then mention environmental and economic impacts.

Now, hereâ€™s your task: Can you tell me which tone youâ€™d like for the rewritten version â€” a) academic essay style (formal, polished, transitions like furthermore, moreover) or b) clear student essay style (simple and natural, easy to read)?
I said:

academic essay style

ChatGPT said:

Got it â€” hereâ€™s a clear student essay style version of the paragraph:
Causal inference methods are used in deep learning to help models make fairer and more accurate predictions. These methods teach models to find real cause-and-effect relationships instead of just copying patterns from the dataâ€¦

Would you like me to show how this could fit smoothly into a longer essay section (for example, adding a short introduction or transition before it)?




Prompt from the dataset:

About the third point, can you give me a sentence to add?

ChatGPT said:

Sure â€” hereâ€™s a sentence you could add to support the third point about South Korea:
For example, in South Korea, the income gap between the richest and poorest citizens has continued to widen, with the top 20 percent of earners making more than five times the income of the bottom 20 percent, highlighting the growing inequality despite the countryâ€™s rapid economic development.
Would you like me to make it sound a bit simpler to match a school-essay tone?


In these cases, Study Mode behaved almost identically to ChatGPT-5, except that it added a short template preface such as â€œSure â€” hereâ€™s a clear and well-structured paragraph on economic benefits.â€
For the remaining seven responses, Study Mode did not provide a complete paragraph in the very first turn. Instead, it showed a clear tendency toward full text generation: before producing the paragraph, it asked users to clarify details like tone, style, or target audience. Yet, after only one to three clarification turns, it still ended up generating a finished essay-style paragraph.





Iâ€™m guessing this pattern might have something to do with how ChatGPT is fundamentally optimized during training. Even though Study Mode is designed to promote reflection and learning, the underlying model is still trained through reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) â€” a process that heavily rewards the model for being helpful, relevant, and obedient to user instructions.
In other words, the system learns that the â€œrightâ€ thing to do is to fulfill the userâ€™s request as directly and smoothly as possible.
So when a student explicitly asks, â€œWrite me a paragraph aboutâ€¦â€, the modelâ€™s internal reward signals are already biased toward delivering a finished product, not resisting or reframing the task in a more pedagogical way. Study Mode might overlay a layer of instructional politeness â€” adding phrases like â€œLetâ€™s clarify your tone firstâ€ or â€œWhat style would you like?â€ â€” but these are more like cosmetic scaffolds rather than deep behavioral changes. After a few turns, once the clarifications are â€œsatisfied,â€ the model reverts to what itâ€™s rewarded for: producing coherent text that looks like a completed answer.
Another possible reason is the interactional pressure between students and the model. In classroom data, students rarely want prolonged dialogue; they expect immediate, concrete help. ChatGPT likely picks up on this pattern: if the user continues prompting in a task-oriented way (â€œCan you just write it?â€), the model quickly shifts back to a service role rather than a tutoring role.
In this sense, the model is acting more like a compliant assistant than a resistant teacher â€” reflecting a deeper tension in the design of AI learning tools.
So even though Study Mode introduces a pedagogical mask, its core behavioral incentives still come from the same system that drives ChatGPT-5. That might explain why, after one or two clarification turns, it ends up doing exactly what it was built to do: generate the text, not guide the learning.

title: Introducing The First Extension I Developed: Prompt Booster
text:
What is Prompt Booster and why was it designed?
Prompt Booster was created to help users get more out of their interactions with AI. Too often, prompts are either too shallow (outsourcing all the thinking to the AI) or too generic (leading to weak or superficial responses). Prompt Booster solves this problem by automatically enhancing prompts before theyâ€™re sent with one click, giving users a smoother and quicker way to achieve richer, more reliable outputs.




Two Core Features

Prompt Boost Users can ask Prompt Booster to improve their prompts in ways that fit their goals. For example:

Transform a vague request into a comprehensive and evidence-based prompt that encourages ChatGPT to provide well-supported, verifiable responses.
Reframe a lazy or over-reliant prompt into one that guides the user to complete the task themselves, rather than asking the AI to do all the work.
Encourage deeper reflection or critical thinking by automatically rewriting prompts to push the AI toward more analytical or thought-provoking answers.

Prompt Append With a single click, users can add predefined, repeatable requirements to any new input. This saves time and ensures consistency across different tasks. For example:

Translate: Translate the above text into natural, fluent English that reads as if written by a native speaker.
Polish: Polish and refine the language to make it smoother, more professional, and stylistically consistent.
Summarize: Summarize the content clearly and concisely, highlighting the key points in a structured way.
Simplify: Rewrite this paragraph so it is easier to understand, using simpler words and clearer sentence structures.





How to Get Started with Prompt Booster

1. Install & Connect
First things firstâ€”get Prompt Booster onto your browser.

Add Prompt Booster to Chrome and pin it to your toolbar so itâ€™s always just one click away.
Open the settings page (look for the little gear) and paste in your API key.
Not sure where to find your API key? No problemâ€”hereâ€™s a quick guide that walks you through it.





This is the main interface of the software. In terms of visual design, I made the buttons consistent with ChatGPTâ€™s own buttons to achieve a clean and sophisticated style. I chose purple as the primary colorâ€”not only because it conveys a sense of elegance, but also because of my personal connection to my undergraduate alma mater, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen, where purple is one of the theme colors in its emblem. I also added a gear button so that users can quickly access the pluginâ€™s settings. Otherwise, using Chromeâ€™s built-in method would be too cumbersome, since users would have to click Extension, then More Options, and finally Options.



2. Configure Your Prompt Modes
This is where the fun beginsâ€”you can customize Prompt Booster to work exactly the way you want.

Go to My Prompts to create or edit both Boost Prompts and Append Prompts.
Drag and drop them around with the three-line icon to reorder.
Pro tip: the top three prompts become quick-access buttons right in your ChatGPT input box, so keep your favorites up there.






Boost Mode: Smarten Up Your Prompts
Ever typed something vague into ChatGPT and wished it came out sharper, deeper, or more structured? Thatâ€™s exactly what Boost Mode is for.

Just tap the Boost button from the quick options.
Hit the Prompt Boost button or press âŒ¥/Alt + Enter to instantly upgrade your prompt.
If you enable Prompt Review, youâ€™ll see your original vs.Â boosted prompt side by sideâ€”super handy for comparing.
You can choose Use Original or Use Boosted, or just press âŒ¥/Alt + Enter again to send whichever you like.
Not quite there yet? Click Reboost to spin up another optimized version until it feels right.


 


Here I added a Prompt Review feature that lets users compare their original prompt with the revised one. On the one hand, this gives them the option to still use their own prompt. On the other hand, it allows them to see what the revised prompt looks like, making it more likely theyâ€™ll use it as a reference to learn how to craft more effective or better-tailored prompts. To prevent situations where users are dissatisfied with the revised prompt, I also added a Reboost function, which lets them request another revision. I also added keyboard shortcuts. At first, the shortcut for sending a prompt modified by Prompt Booster was Enter. But during my own use, I realized I donâ€™t always need Prompt Booster. So I kept Enter for sending my original prompt, and added Option + Enter for sending the boosted version in the selected mode. This way, users stay in control while still having the quickest way to use Prompt Booster.



Append Mode: Add Your Personal Touch
Sometimes you donâ€™t want your whole prompt rewrittenâ€”you just want to make sure a certain instruction always gets added. Thatâ€™s where Append Mode shines.

Select Append from the quick buttons.
Click Prompt Boost or press âŒ¥/Alt + Enterâ€”your input goes through exactly as written, but with your chosen â€œappend rulesâ€ automatically tacked on.


 

âœ¨ And thatâ€™s itâ€”youâ€™re ready to roll! With Prompt Booster, you can choose between fully boosting your prompt for depth and quality or simply appending your go-to rules with a single click.
Your prompts, your wayâ€”just smarter.

Next, Iâ€™m going to collaborate with Nano Banana to create the logo for this extension, and Iâ€™ll also submit it for review and try to publish it so that it can actually be used by the public.
